header.name: chaos/preprocessor/repetition/delineate_shifted_params.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that delineates a sequence of preprocessing tokens a specified number of times.

macro.abstract: The macro repeats its third argument--concatenated to the current repetition number--one less time than the number specified by its first argument with the delineator specified by its second argument between each repetition.

macro.para:
This macro expands to the result of repeating param or __VA_ARGS__ (concatenated to the current repetition number) count - 1 times (with the delineate specified by sep between each repetition). This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code (where N is count - 1):
param ## 1 sep() param ## 2 sep() ... param ## N

The rightmost preprocessing token of param or __VA_ARGS__ must be either pasteable to a number or be a binary parenthetic expression such as
(a, b)
If param or __VA_ARGS__ is a binary parenthetic expression, this macro extracts the two elements and concatenates the current repetition number to each of them. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code (where N is again count - 1):
a ## 1 b ## 1 sep() a ## 2 b ## 2 sep() ... a ## N b ## N
In C99, the requirement that a parenthetic expression must be binary is relaxed. It can be any arity provided that there are at least two elements.
(a, ...)
In that circumstance, the current repetition number is concatenated to both the first of the two elements and to the all the rest of the elements as a single unit.

This secondary mechanism is intended to make it easy to define parameter lists, such as the following:
T1 p1, T2 p2, ... T3 p3
